docs.lead_paragraph: Years ago, when I was a reporter in Texas, I interviewed a retired country doctor, out in ranch country, who had delivered generations of babies. He was known -- in the days before ultrasound and amnio -- for his uncanny ability to predict the sex of an unborn child.

headline.main: When the Gender Prediction Is Wrong

docs.abstract: Is it a boy or a girl? That is a question couples can choose to answer it at a number of different moments in a pregnancy, and the one we choose can speak volumes about how we view the world.
docs.snippet: Is it a boy or a girl? That is a question couples can choose to answer it at a number of different moments in a pregnancy, and the one we choose can speak volumes about how we view the world.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several posts (Nos. 13, 32, 71, 74, 98) berated me for wasting time on something as trivial as a comedian's joke. One comment (No. 41) even suggested a couple of more apt topics: "the looming conflict in Iran and the impending threat of North Korea." Let me reassure you that the news pages of The Times devote much attention to just those things. And I hope it is not tactless to mention that my topic is not so trivial as to keep my critics themselves from commenting on it. But I quite like these putatively unimportant matters. They are a culture's unguarded moments. Examining them can yield glimpses of our assumptions about - as here - power, family and sex. In any case, the persistence of murder doesn't require us to ignore burglary.
